questions.question: You went there yesterday, ………………………?
questions.description: Use a negative tag after an affirmative statement. In the simple past tense, use did in question tags.

questions.question: You had a word with your boss, …………………..?
questions.description: Use did because this sentence is in the simple past tense.

questions.question: She told you something, ……………………………?
questions.description: Use a negative tag after an affirmative statement. In the simple past tense, use did in question tags.

questions.question: They live here, ………………………………?
questions.description: In the simple present tense, use do or does to make question tags.

questions.question: She is an architect, ……………………….?
questions.description: The auxiliary verb in the given statement is repeated in the question tag.

questions.question: She earns a six figure salary, ……………………….?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after a negative statement. In the simple present tense, use do or does.

questions.question: He spends a lot of money on gadgets, …………………………?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after a negative statement. In the simple present tense, use do or does.

questions.question: Somebody knocked on the door, ………………………….?
questions.description: Use they to refer to somebody, anybody, nobody etc in question tags.

questions.question: That boy remembers everything, ……………………………?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after a negative statement. In the simple present tense, use do or does.

questions.question: Our team lost the match, ……………………………?
questions.description: Use a negative tag after an affirmative statement. In the simple past tense, use did in question tags.

questions.question: She travels around the world, …………………………..?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after a negative statement. In the simple present tense, use do or does.

questions.question: You don’t know him, …………………………………..?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after a negative statement. In the simple present tense, use do or does.

questions.question: You know everything, …………………………?
questions.description: A negative tag is after an affirmative sentence. In the simple present tense, use do or does in the question tag.

questions.question: She helped you, ………………………….?
questions.description: In the simple past tense, use did in the question tag.

questions.question: He does hardly anything, …………………………..?
questions.description: An affirmative tag is used after negative expressions like hardly or nothing.

questions.question: She bakes cakes, …………………………….?
questions.description: In the simple present tense, use do or does in the question tag.

questions.question: You did not do it, …………………………….?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after a negative statement.

questions.question: There is no one in that room, …………………………….?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after negative expressions like no one.

questions.question: She refused to go, ……………………………….?
questions.description: In the simple past tense, use did in the question tag.

questions.question: No one is ready to go, ……………………………?
questions.description: We use they in question tags after nobody or no one.

questions.question: You don’t know the answer, ……………………….?
questions.description: Affirmative tags are used after negative sentences.

questions.question: He is disappointed with his results, ………………………….?
He drove as fast as he could, ………………………….?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: Whenever we play chess, Ann beats me, ……………………….?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: He recognized you, ……………………………?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: He wants to be an architect, ………………………….?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: He was dead by the time they found him, ………………………..?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: He called me names, …………………………..?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: He broke his leg while playing football, …………………………..?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: She never wastes an opportunity to degrade me, ……………………………?
questions.description: Affirmative tags are used after words like never.

questions.question: They stopped him, ……………………………
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences.

questions.question: He will not permit this, …………………………?
questions.description: Affirmative tags are used after negative sentences.

questions.question: No one knows the answer, ………………………?
questions.description: Use they in question tags after no one, someone, anyone etc.

questions.question: He has few friends, ……………………………?
questions.description: Use an affirmative tag after negative expressions like few.

questions.question: He makes a few friends wherever he goes, ………………………….?
questions.description: Use a negative tag after a few.

questions.question: She passed the test, ………………………….?
questions.description: When the sentence is in the simple past, use did in the tag question.

questions.question: He wants to be a scientist, ………………………….?
They dare not attack us, …………………………..?
questions.description: When dare is a modal auxiliary, it is used in the question tag.

questions.question: He dared to swim across the channel, …………………………..?
He hasn’t arrived, ……………………..?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences and non-negative tags are used after negative sentences. If the main sentence has an auxiliary it is repeated in the question tag.

questions.question: Sam left in the morning, ……………………..?
questions.description:
Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences and non-negative tags are used after negative sentences.
If the main sentence does not have an auxiliary, the tag is made with do, does or did.

questions.question: You live with him, …………………………?
questions.description:
Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences and non-negative tags are used after negative sentences.
If the main sentence does not have an auxiliary, the tag is made with do, does or did.

questions.description:
Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences and non-negative tags are used after negative sentences.
If the main sentence does not have an auxiliary, the tag is made with do, does or did.

questions.question: He married his childhood sweet heart, ………………………..?
questions.description:
Negative tags are used after affirmative sentences and non-negative tags are used after negative sentences.
If the main sentence does not have an auxiliary, the tag is made with do, does or did.

questions.question: Edison was not a brilliant student, ………………………..?
You slept the whole day yesterday, ………………………….?
The children delivered a splendid performance, …………………………?

questions.description: If the main verb does not have an auxiliary verb, the question tag uses do, does or did.

questions.question: The earth is not flat, ……………………………?
questions.description: If the main verb has an auxiliary, it is repeated in the question tag.

questions.question: Mini speaks German, ……………………………..?
questions.description: If the main verb does not have an auxiliary verb, the question tag uses do, does or did.

questions.question: She visited Germany last year, ………………………….?
questions.description: If the main verb does not have an auxiliary verb, the question tag uses do, does or did.

questions.question: She has no house of her own, …………………………….?
She hardly ate anything, ………………………….?
questions.description: Affirmative tags are used after negative words like hardly.

questions.question: Let’s eat something, ……………………………..?
questions.description: Shall we is used after let's.

questions.question: Few students knew the answer, ………………………..?
questions.description: Few has a negative meaning. Hence, a non-negative tag is used after it.

questions.question: No one knows the answer, ……………………………..?
questions.description: Non-negative tags are used after negative statements.

questions.question: Children enjoy playing, ………………………………..?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative statements

questions.question: We must leave now, …………………………?
questions.description: If the main sentence has an auxiliary verb, it is repeated in the question tag.

questions.question: The children were playing outside, …………………………..?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative statements.

questions.question: The wise man can solve our problem, ………………………….?
questions.description: Negative tags are used after affirmative statements.

questions.question: I am working hard, …………………………….?
questions.description: The question tag for I am is aren’t I?

questions.question: You are the winner of the prize, ……………………………..?
One picture is worth a thousand words, ………………………….?
Nothing can happen, ……………………………?
questions.description: Nothing is a negative word hence an affirmative tag is used after it. In tags, we use it to refer to nothing.

questions.question: Somebody wanted a drink, ……………………………?
questions.description: In tags we use they to refer to somebody/anybody.

questions.question: She has a sister, …………………………..?
questions.description: When have refers to a state, question tags with have and do are both possible.

questions.question: Shut up, …………………………..?
questions.description: After imperatives, we use will/would/can/can’t/could you? to ask people to do things.

questions.question: She works here, ………………………….?
questions.description: When the given sentence is in the simple present tense, we use do/does in the tag.

questions.question: It is a cold day, ……………………….?
questions.description: We use a negative tag after an affirmative sentence. The auxiliary verb used in the question tag is the same as the auxiliary verb in the statement.

questions.question: Diana is very clever, ……………………….?
questions.description: We use a negative tag after an affirmative sentence. The auxiliary verb used in the question tag is the same as the auxiliary verb in the statement.

questions.question: He has finished his work, …………………………..?
questions.description: We use a negative tag after an affirmative sentence. The auxiliary verb used in the question tag is the same as the auxiliary verb in the statement.

questions.question: Robert lives in Singapore, ………………………….?
questions.description: When the statement is in the simple present tense, we use do or does in the question tag.

questions.question: He is older than you, ……………………………?
questions.description: We use a negative tag after an affirmative sentence. The auxiliary verb used in the question tag is the same as the auxiliary verb in the statement.

questions.question: You met him yesterday, ……………………………….?
questions.description: When the statement is in the simple past, we make question tag with did.

questions.question: You took the money, ……………………………..?
questions.description: We use a negative tag after an affirmative sentence.

questions.question: Let’s go for a walk, …………………………?
questions.description: After let's, we use shall we in the question tag.

questions.question: He wants to be a scientist, ……………………………..?
questions.description: When the statement is in the simple present tense, we use do or does in the question tag.

questions.question: I’m right, ………………..?
questions.description: The question tag for I’m is aren’t I.

questions.question: Shut up, …………………?
questions.description: After imperatives will you, would you, can you, can’t you or couldn’t you can be used to tell people to do things.

questions.question: Don’t forget, ………………?
questions.description: After negative imperatives, we use ‘will you?’

questions.question: Move a bit, ……………..?
questions.description: After imperatives will you, would you, can you, can’t you or couldn’t you can be used to tell people to do things.

questions.question: Let’s go for a walk, …………………?
questions.description: After let’s we use ‘shall we?’

questions.question: You never say what you are going, …………………?
questions.description: Non-negative tags are used after negative words like never, no, nobody, hardly etc.

questions.question: There is little we can do about it, ……………….?
questions.description: Non-negative tags are used after negative words like never, no, little, nobody, hardly etc.

questions.question: Somebody wanted a pizza, …………………..?
questions.description: We use they to refer to somebody, nobody and everybody.

questions.question: He has a daughter, ………………..?
questions.description: When have is used as a main verb, question tags with both have and do are possible.

questions.question: There weren’t any issues, ………………..?
questions.description: There can be used as a subject in question tags.

questions.question: Ravi wants to be an actor, ………………..?
You are not joining the strike, …………………?
He used to play cricket when he was young, ………………….?
The meeting is at four o’clock, ………………………………?
